Rather than sticking firmly to their ideal outcomes, a spirit of give-and-take and a willingness to make concessions on lower priority issues in exchange for agreement on higher priority ones will be essential.

Tactically, it may help to break the negotiation down into smaller components rather than putting forth comprehensive all-or-nothing proposals. Reaching incremental agreements on specific issues and building trust through a pattern of successful compromises could pave the way for an ultimate package deal.

The parties should also invest time in explaining their underlying interests and the reasoning behind their positions. Developing a deeper understanding of each side's needs, concerns and constraints can open up creative solutions that satisfy everyone's core interests, even if in an unexpected form.

Finally, exploring additional issues that could be added to the negotiation, perhaps ones of particular interest to certain parties, could expand the zone of possible agreement by allowing trade-offs across a broader set of topics. The key is shifting from positional bargaining to an interest-based approach focused on creating value and finding mutually beneficial outcomes. It will take flexibility, empathy and innovative thinking, but with good faith effort a win-win agreement should be achievable.
